awd_titl_txt: Financial, Mentoring, Curricular, and Co-Curricular Supports to Increase Student Completion of Transfer Degrees in Biology, Chemistry, and Earth Science
awd_abstract_narration:
The NSF Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) program supports the retention and graduation of high-achieving, low-income students with demonstrated financial need.  This project at Spokane Community College will provide financial, academic, and professional support to 36 high achieving, low-income students, with emphasis on students from rural high schools.  The students will be enrolled in associate degree transfer programs in biology, chemistry, or earth science.  The need for more college graduates in STEM fields is well documented, yet many students who enter college interested in these subjects fail to graduate. In addition to providing financial support, this project will engage these students in activities designed to increase their success at Spokane Community College and matriculation to a four year college to pursue a bachelor's degree in STEM.   Activities will include dedicated academic advising, tutoring, peer and professional mentoring, undergraduate research, guided career exploration, and community service.  A collaboration with Washington State University College of Education will provide insight into effective interventions for increasing STEM student success rates, thus helping the project meet its goals.  This collaboration will also explore which approaches contribute to STEM student success at community and four year colleges. It is expected that this project will support students' academic goals and help to meet regional business and industry workforce needs.   

The project will use multiple strategies to improve the systemic recruitment of high achieving, low-income students and guide their successful completion of a two-year transfer college degree in the sciences. Scholarships provided through this project will provide the economic means for students to focus on their academic goals. These scholarships, in combination with advising/mentoring by STEM faculty and curricular/co-curricular supports will increase student success as measured by the scholars' persistence and completion of transfer degrees in biological sciences, chemistry, and earth science. Results of the program evaluation studies will provide insights to drive changes in institutional practice that will improve Spokane Community College's future success in recruiting academically talented low-income students and supporting completion of STEM transfer degrees. The knowledge acquired through this program will be disseminated through publications and presentations to further the national goal of increasing STEM student success, particularly among low-income students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our NSF S-STEM award aimed to provide financial, academic, and holistic support to science students at Spokane Community College while evaluating whether those supports increased student success. Students were eligible for our SCC Science Scholars program if they had unmet financial need and a declared major in the sciences. Our first three cohorts emphasized participation from physical and biological science majors.

The program initially had challenges recruiting eligible students, with requirements for credit load and GPA presenting the most significant hurdles. The COVID-19 pandemic also impacted recruitment, most noticeably during the second year. Adjustments were made repeatedly to increase student applications, as allowed by the grant requirements. The program was eventually opened to all science students with a 50% credit load and unmet financial need. In total, 34 individual students participated in the program as part of four cohorts.

Students who participated in the program received scholarships, mentoring, opportunities to participate in field trips, and social support through cohort-based activities. Students reported that each of these elements increased their commitment to completing their degree program. In particular, students said that the recognition of receiving the scholarship and the connections they formed with their faculty mentors had the most significant impact on their desire to perform academically, but their connection to their cohort was essential to feeling that they belonged in the sciences and at college. During the COVID-19 pandemic, when classes were moved entirely online, students who had already formed a connection to their cohort showed better outcomes than students who had not.

Here are three other important findings from the SCC Science Scholars Program:

  • 60% of those who received the scholarships and holistic support transferred to a four-year school for a science degree. This is higher than the transfer rate for all declared SCC transfer students (51%) and much higher than declared SCC transfer students with financial need (24%). This indicates that scholarships with holistic support improve transfer rates significantly.
  • Students who dropped out of the program were twice as likely to do so for family and health reasons than for academic reasons. 22% of the students receiving scholarships and holistic support also accepted mental health counseling during their time at SCC. This indicates that an effective college must support the whole student to maximize student success.
  • The difficulty recruiting students indicates the complexities of applying rigid standards to a diverse and non-traditional student body. For example, students who attended school part-time were initially not eligible for the program, discouraging applications from students with significant work and family commitments. During the first year of recruiting, 40% of the applications and inquiries we received were from students deemed ineligible due to technical parameters with financial aid or credit load. This indicates that the constraints set for programs at four-year colleges should be critically reevaluated before use at community colleges and with non-traditional student bodies.

In total, 34 students participated in the program between 2019 and 2024. We are proud of all these students for their hard work at SCC. We thank the National Science Foundation for supporting this project, and others like it, through the NSF S-STEM grant program.

 


Last Modified: 11/01/2024
Modified by: Jaye Hopkins
